support_summary: alpha-tubulin is a well-established substrate of HDAC6, which deacetylates it at Lys40, affecting microtubule stability and dynamics.

functions.cellular_process: HDAC6 directly binds to and deacetylates alpha-tubulin at lysine 40 (Lys40). This post-translational modification is a key regulatory step in controlling the stability and dynamics of the microtubule network.
functions.effect_description: The deacetylation of alpha-tubulin by HDAC6 results in less stable microtubules. This leads to an increase in microtubule turnover and dynamics, which in turn affects various cellular processes.
biological_consequence: HDAC6 binds to β-tubulin, recruiting it to microtubule polymers → HDAC6 deacetylates Lys40 on α-tubulin within the microtubule lattice → Decreased microtubule stability and increased microtubule dynamics → Enhanced cell motility and migration.
specific_effects: Overexpression of HDAC6 leads to global hypoacetylation of α-tubulin.
Inhibition of HDAC6, either pharmacologically or genetically, results in the hyperacetylation of tubulin and microtubules.
Deacetylation of alpha-tubulin by HDAC6 promotes chemotactic cell movement.

evidence.paper_title: HDAC-6 interacts with and deacetylates tubulin and microtubules in vivo
evidence.relevant_quote: Reversible acetylation on the ε-amino group of α-tubulin Lys40 marks stabilized microtubule structures and may contribute to regulating microtubule dynamics... We find that HDAC-6 is a micro tubule-associated protein capable of deacetylating α-tubulin in vivo and in vitro.

evidence.paper_title: Histone deacetylase 6 (HDAC6) is an independent deacetylase for alpha-tubulin
evidence.relevant_quote: The results clearly demonstrated that interaction between HDAC6 and tubulin is independent of other proteins. In addition, HDAC6 can independently catalyze deacetylation of both tubulin dimer and microtubule polymer.
